chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reform should keep states’ role in running elections while making presidential outcomes track voter intent more closely and reducing the outsized power of a few swing states. A workable middle path is to curb winner‑take‑all by adopting proportional allocation (with a small, transparent minimum to address small‑state concerns) and to set a national fallback that awards the presidency to the national popular‑vote winner if the Electoral College result diverges beyond a clear margin. Any transition should be phased in and paired with baseline standards for paper records, risk‑limiting audits, consistent recount triggers, and elector binding to certified results to strengthen legitimacy regardless of the method used.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Pursue an incremental reform that preserves states’ role in administering elections while making presidential outcomes track the popular will more closely: encourage states to end winner‑take‑all by adopting proportional (or district-based) elector allocation, and keep the National Popular Vote interstate compact as a practical pathway where politically feasible. Pair any allocation change with ranked‑choice or runoff rules to ensure the winner has broad support and to reduce spoiler effects. Anchor the transition in clear national minimum standards—paper ballots, routine risk‑limiting audits, uniform recount triggers, and nonpartisan certification—so results are transparent, auditable, and widely accepted.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform should keep states’ central role in running elections while making presidential outcomes track voters more closely and reducing winner‑take‑all distortions; a realistic path is to encourage proportional (or district-based with anti‑gerrymandering rules) allocation of electors and to consider the National Popular Vote compact once it has broad, durable support. To protect smaller and rural states and avoid razor‑thin legitimacy fights, include clear national minimum standards for secure paper ballots, transparent audits, and uniform recount triggers. Where states are willing, ranked‑choice or runoff rules can help ensure the winner has broad support and reduce spoiler concerns.
